metadata.titleEn: Qilian Mountains integrated observatory network: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network (eddy covariance system of mixed forest station, 2021)
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from the mixed forest station eddy covariance system (EC) in the downstream reaches of the Heihe integrated observatory network from January 1 to December 31 in 2021. The site (101.1335° E, 41.9903° N) was located in the Sidaoqiao County, in Ejina Banner in Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region . The elevation is 874 m. The EC was installed at a height of 3.2 m, and the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the separation distance between the sonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O gas analyzer (CSAT3B & Li7500DS) was 0.17 m.
The raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Eddypro post-processing software, including the spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. The observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC): class 1-3 (high quality), class 4-6 (good), class 7-8 (poor, better than gap filling data), class9 (rejected). In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data collected before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 10% of the 30 min raw record. There were 48 records per day, and the missing data were replaced with -6999. Suspicious data were marked in red. The water vapor density data were rejected when the negative values occurred. CO2 data were missing due to the sensor malfunction after November 3.
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xls format. Detailed information can be found in the suggested references.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What is the concept of 'eddy covariance system' in data collection for surface process observations?
Definition.Answer: An eddy covariance system in data collection is a method used to measure and calculate vertical turbulent fluxes within the atmosphere. It typically involves high-frequency measurements of wind speed, temperature, and trace gas concentrations (such as CO2 and H2O) to assess exchanges of energy, water vapor, and carbon between the land surface and the atmosphere.

Definition.Question: What does 'quality evaluation of flux measurements' entail in the context of atmospheric data collection?
Definition.Answer: Quality evaluation of flux measurements in atmospheric data collection involves assessing the reliability and accuracy of the data obtained from instruments, like the eddy covariance system. It includes checks for atmospheric stability, turbulence similarity characteristics, and filtering of data based on errors from instruments, precipitation events, or high data loss in the raw dataset.

Definition.Question: What are the challenges associated with long-term observational datasets in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Definition.Answer: Challenges associated with long-term observational datasets in oasis-desert ecosystems include issues such as ecological environment degradation, like the drying up of rivers and lakes, land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These factors can complicate data collection and affect the quality and continuity of the datasets.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data collection frequency and data types between the mixed forest station and the oasis–desert systems?
Comparison.Answer: The mixed forest station collects 10Hz raw data, processed into 30-minute intervals, while the oasis–desert systems acquire half-hourly turbulent flux data and additional data with a 10-minute average period. The mixed forest station focuses on parameters like wind direction, temperature, and CO2 concentration, whereas oasis–desert systems include a broader range of hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil parameters.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges faced in inland river basins impact data collection compared to those faced in the mixed forest station?
Comparison.Answer: Inland river basins face challenges such as ecological degradation, drying rivers, and land desertification, which can affect data collection by introducing variability and environmental stresses not present in the more stable mixed forest station environment. These challenges necessitate careful monitoring and adaptation in data collection methodologies to ensure accurate and relevant data.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise in maintaining data quality and consistency when collecting long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon flux data in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in maintaining data quality and consistency can include the degradation of ecological environments such as drying rivers and lakes, land desertification, and frequent dust storms. These environmental changes can affect the stability of data collection instruments and introduce errors in measurements. Additionally, issues such as instrument malfunctions, data loss during extreme weather events, and variations in atmospheric conditions can complicate the accurate collection and processing of flux data.

Interpretation.Question: What implications do the patterns of energy and carbon exchange observed in oasis–desert areas have for understanding broader ecological and climate dynamics in arid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The patterns of energy and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas can provide insights into the ecological balance and carbon cycling in arid regions. Observations indicating that these areas act as carbon sinks suggest their crucial role in offsetting regional carbon emissions and maintaining ecological stability. These patterns can also inform strategies for sustainable development and conservation efforts, particularly in the context of climate change and the expansion of drylands.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the quality assessment of flux data in oasis-desert ecosystems, and how are these assessments conducted?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The quality assessment of flux data in oasis-desert ecosystems involves evaluating data based on parameters like atmospheric stationarity and turbulence similarity characteristics. The data processing techniques include despiking, time delay correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, and density correction. The quality of the flux data is further classified into nine levels, with levels 1 to 3 indicating good quality.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it necessary to apply data corrections, such as delay time correction and coordinate rotation, when processing eddy covariance data in arid regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Data corrections like delay time correction and coordinate rotation are necessary to accurately account for the time lag in sensor response and to align the coordinate system of measurements with the mean wind direction. These corrections help in obtaining precise measurements of fluxes like heat, water vapor, and carbon dioxide, which are crucial for understanding energy and material exchanges in arid and semi-arid ecosystems.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the primary challenges faced in maintaining long-term observations of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in arid regions, and how do these challenges affect data collection?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The primary challenges in maintaining long-term observations in arid regions include ecological degradation such as drying of water bodies, vegetation degradation, land desertification, and dust storms. These factors can disrupt data collection, lead to gaps in datasets, and necessitate rigorous data processing and quality control measures to ensure the reliability and continuity of the data collected over time.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using Eddypro software for processing turbulent flux data on the quality and reliability of the data collected from oasis-desert ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using Eddypro software for processing turbulent flux data can lead to more reliable and quality-controlled data due to steps like outlier removal, delay time correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, and density correction. This enhances the data's accuracy and aids in quality evaluation via atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity testing, allowing for better assessment of oasis-desert interactions.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the challenges of ecological degradation in inland river basins influence the methods and frequency of data collection in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The challenges of ecological degradation in inland river basins could necessitate more frequent and comprehensive data collection, including long-term observations and diverse datasets covering energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges. Such extensive data collection efforts are crucial for understanding and mitigating the effects of phenomena like river and lake drying, vegetation degradation, and desertification on oasis-desert systems.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the consequences of integrating hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil parameter datasets with turbulent flux data for understanding carbon exchange in oasis-desert areas?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil parameter datasets with turbulent flux data could lead to a more nuanced understanding of carbon exchange in oasis-desert areas. This comprehensive approach allows for exploring interactions between various environmental factors and their impact on carbon cycling, potentially improving strategies for ecological stability and sustainable development in these regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are eddy covariance systems utilized to collect long-term data on energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Eddy covariance systems, such as those mentioned with a sampling frequency of 10Hz, are used to collect half-hourly turbulent flux data. The data include measurements of wind direction, horizontal wind speed, and other parameters, which are then processed to ensure quality and accuracy. This involves steps like coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, and quality assessment based on atmospheric stability and similarity tests.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the main challenges faced in data collection and quality control for ecological monitoring in arid and semiarid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Challenges in these regions include ecological degradation such as drying rivers, land desertification, and frequent dust storms. The quality control procedures must address issues like instrument malfunction, data loss due to adverse weather conditions, and the removal of erroneous data, particularly during precipitation events or when significant data gaps exist.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are implemented to ensure the accuracy and reliability of flux data collected from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To ensure accuracy, data from eddy covariance systems undergo preprocessing with steps like outlier removal, time delay correction, and multiple coordinate rotations. The datasets are further refined by excluding data collected during instrument errors, immediately before or after precipitation, and when the original data has a significant proportion of missing values. Data quality is assessed through specific quality flags that categorize data based on reliability.

Enablement.Question: What data processing techniques enable the transformation of raw 10Hz data into usable 30-minute data intervals for surface flux measurements?
Enablement.Answer: The data processing techniques include outlier removal, time delay correction, coordinate rotation (double rotation), frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, and density (WPL) correction. Additionally, quality evaluations for each flux value are performed, primarily testing for atmospheric stationarity (Δst) and turbulence similarity characteristics (ITC).

Enablement.Question: What infrastructure and technological setups enable the continuous collection of hydrometeorological and turbulent flux data in remote desert and oasis environments?
Enablement.Answer: The infrastructure includes an eddy covariance system and scintillometer for turbulent flux data, as well as automatic weather stations for hydrometeorological data. These setups record information on radiation, soil heat flux, temperature profiles, wind speed and direction, air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture, with data collected at various intervals, such as 10-minute averages.
